7- Always convey that individual and structural change are both indisputably necessary

4- Make your activism intersectional, include all stakeholders in your decision making, and donâ€™t tokenize

5- Just for the sake of efficiency, donâ€™t do things the patriarchal way, the racist way, the exhausting way, or any way that excludes marginalized voices

Using #AntiFossilFuelNorms, Anti-fossil fuel initiatives, help to concentrate moral pressure on the largest culprits of climate change, [the fossil fuel industry] which makes such initiatives more effective at inspiring public anger/indignation.

#AntiFossilFuelNorms personalize the causes of climate change, thus strengthening the intuitiveness of their moral wrongness and more readily triggering feelings of indignation, compared with a climate change frame.

#AntiFossilFuelNorms are amenable to framing using clear and simple language. Fossil fuels and associated infrastructure are readily understood by non-activists. In contrast, concepts such as greenhouse gases, â€œ2Â°C average warmingâ€, and â€œ350 ppmâ€ are abstract & technical.

#AntiFossilFuelNorms are already being modeled & championed, this is a new effective tactic. 
Easily understood by all, it also addresses issues such as local environmental, health & social impacts, corruption, repressive governance practices, human rights abuses, etc.

4<U+20E3> Leave no voice or solution behind.

2<U+20E3> Itâ€™s time to wrap it up and implement.
Itâ€™s time to wrap up outstanding items & negotiations and implement the #ParisAgreement. Weâ€™ve been 5 years negotiating. The clock has run out.

The Balanced Pathway to deliver our recommended targets in Wales involves a large sustained increase in investment in Wales, adding around Â£3 billion annually by 2030 as part of UK-wide investments of around Â£50 billion by 2030. (6/12) https://t.co/HXYDM2MnH0

The credibility of the UKâ€™s Sixth Carbon Budget (2033-37) and Net Zero rests on action in all parts of the UK, including Wales. Around 10% of the action in our Balanced Net Zero Pathway for the UK during the Sixth Carbon Budget period will be delivered in Wales. (5/12) https://t.co/PE11gBk4Lt

Wales should now legislate a series of targets to meet Net Zero. Meeting the Sixth Carbon Budget will require action across four key areas; reducing demand for carbon-intensive activities, increased take-up of low carbon solutions, expansion of low-carbon energy supplies and in transforming the UKâ€™s land. (10/12) #UKCarbonBudget https://t.co/bCOELMuU7z

This required investment programme can provide a significant economic boost in the coming years and support the UKâ€™s economic recovery from COVID-19. Our pathway also involves considerable opportunities for job creation. (7/12) #UKCarbonBudget https://t.co/betd9i3hXf

Our estimate of the annualised resource cost (which measures the net additional cost each year to deliver the same services with lower emissions) has fallen to less than 1% of GDP through to 2050. (5/12) #UKCarbonBudget https://t.co/eTS1Gjm74T

Perhaps the most important reflection is that local decisions can have national and even international implications when it comes to climate change. That demands full consideration. Weâ€™ve offered our assistance in helping to frame some guidance for local councillors and planners.

That said, the project has implications we wanted to highlight:

- The mine will increase global emissions and make it harder to achieve the UK carbon budgets

- Based on our CB6 advice, the coal produced may not have a use in the UK after 2035 (most is projected to be exported)

Fairly obviously, a new coal mine is not a great look for the UK in the year before the COP26 Presidency. But @theCCCuk is not a regulator or a planning authority (nor do we wish to become one). This is a legally consented commercial development.

We have written to the MHCLG Secretary of State to outline our concerns about the recent decision to give planning permission for a new Cumbrian deep coal mine, which is due to produce 'coking coal' for steel.

Itâ€™s the hope that kills you â€“ but I'm pretty positive about the impact this review could have on the strategic decisions on tax and public spending before the Chancellor for the Budget and the next spending review next year.

But I think this interim review sets up the strategic questions pretty well.

Itâ€™s a thoughtful report too â€“ with messages that made me think , about the costs of the transition that we havenâ€™t fully considered: retraining and skills provision for example.

Chapter two is the one to read with references to the fiscal implications and this chart. A whopping Â£35bn+ of Exchequer revenues from fossil fuel consumption.

There are 27 billion reasons for the Chancellor to get thinking about the future of fuel duties in a zero carbon world. https://t.co/JljscXDzNb

Sadly, not many clues on where policy is heading â€“ unsurprising in an interim review â€“ especially the fiscal policies. Tantalising references to transport taxes, but nothing that tells me what the answer is if we all go electric. Likewise, domestic heating and energy bills.

This is the Treasury acknowledging (embracing?) the structural changes in the economy implied by Net Zero. Thatâ€™s good, because it should move us fundamentally from the old paradigm that decarbonisation was an annoying cost to be managed.

Those of you steeped in climate policy might not regard these as gamechanging â€“ but it really is *good* to see the UKâ€™s economics and finance Ministry enshrining these principles. 

A sensible economic outlook from the department that once brought you the Stern Review.

6) Households are exposed to the transition through their consumption, labour market participation and asset holdings. Government needs to consider these patterns of exposure in designing policies for the transition.
5) The risk of carbon leakage will increase with efforts to reduce emissions.
4) Well-designed policy can reduce costs and risk for investors, support innovation and the deployment of new technologies.
3) Government needs to use a mix of policy levers to address multiple market failures and support decarbonisation.
2) The costs of the transition to net zero are uncertain and depend on policy choices.

Their insights:
1) The combined effect of UK and global climate action on UK economic growth is likely to be relatively small. The scale, distribution and balance of new growth opportunities and challenges will depend on how the economy and policy respond to the changes required.

2021 needs to be the year when the UKâ€™s climate commitments are â€˜levelled-upâ€™ to coin a phrase you may have heard, so that adaptation planning and our resilience to climate hazards take greater prominence.

Mitigation and adaptation are often discussed as two sides of the same coin. Never sure thatâ€™s right â€“ clearly they are both related to climate change but they're very different disciplines (with a few overlapping areas).

Nonetheless not all of our recommendations were agreed.

That distinction matters because inclusion of adaptation plans in the NDC would require new commitments.

Publishing a *communication* on adaptation (which is a very good publication) means that the focus is more on the UKâ€™s procedures and legal framework for adaptation planning.

The CBI welcomes this yearâ€™s Progress Report to Parliament from @theCCCuk. Within it holds the keys to some critical & immediate policy decisions that must be made not just to get us on track to #netzero but to help the UK recover from #COVID19 <U+0001F30D><U+0001F331><U+26A1><U+FE0F><U+0001F447> https://t.co/yD9nndZjeS

Principle 5: UK should accelerate coordinating a global response. Build business into the plans for #COP26, use international policies to help cut emissions, and create clean investment dialogues with other countries.

Principle 4: Build the foundations of a green economic recovery into plans to support companies recovering from the pandemic. Ensure support for sustainability is built into the foundation of longer-term financial mechanisms helping companies as the UK moves to recovery phase

Principle 3: UK Government should look beyond the fiscal remit to drive investment and stimulate a green recovery through smarter regulation and clear policy. Confirm end date for new ICE vehicle sales, Energy White Paper+National Infra Strat,+timeline for future home standards

Principle 2: With the help of the private sector, deliver on existing fiscal commitments from the Budget to leverage investment and cut emissions. Progress #renewable and #nuclear power, incentives for low-emission vehicles, and #CCUS funding.

Principle 1: Prioritise public spending and policy on low-carbon programmes that deliver short-term economic and social benefits and lay the foundations for a resilient, net-zero economy. Energy efficiency spend, and developing skills and training programmes needed for #netzero

We have published our paper on the priorities for a green recovery following the coronavirus pandemic. We set out 5 key principles, underpinned by priority policy actions to help deliver jobs around the UK and accelerate progress to #netzero

So welcome moves, but needs to be the start of further action from across government this year. Progress needed on #energyefficiency, #nuclear, #battery storage and smart grids, #hydrogen, future homes standards. <U+0001F440>for Energy White Paper and National Infrastructure Strategy

CBI call for extension of Plug-In Car and Van Grants has been heard (Â£430m committed), and Â£500m to support the roll-out of rapid charging infrastructure. Very important to see this as we seek to tackle road transport emissions. #EVs

Some moves on heat, with a new Low-Carbon Heat Support Scheme to support heat pumps/biomass; also RHI clarity, support for more green gas, and Â£270m for heat networks to adopt low-carbon heat sources. Much more action required, but this is a positive start!

Industrial energy efficiency is being supported by the re-opening and extension of the Climate Change Agreement (CCA) scheme by two years. This will be consulted on, along with long-term options for the CCA scheme.

Power/industrial sectors have also benefit from clarity on future trajectory of the Carbon Price Support mechanism (frozen for another year), and government plans to consult this year on a UK Emissions Trading System (linked to the EU ETS), and a fall-back carbon emissions tax

Â£800m confirmed for deliver two industrial #CCUS clusters by 2030, plus additional support for the UK's first gas power station with CCUS by the end of the decade. We called for this funding, and hope it is a catalyst for further action on investment and business models

We call on countries to honour their commitment to the #ParisAgreement & to ensure that updated NDCs are a product of collaborative processes, raise ambition significantly & are in line with principles of equity & fairshares to keep warming below #1o5C
https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X

The @UNFCCC needs to ensure that the ratchet mechanism, an essential part of the Paris Agreement, is functional. Brazil's NDC should not be accepted under the #ParisAgreement, much less welcomed. This sets a worrying precedent and can weaken the #ParisAgreement

Citing the need for $10 billion a year to meet its climate targets when the previous intended NDC stated that Brazilâ€™s climate goals were not contingent on international support shows the complete lack of clarity in Brazilâ€™s new NDC. 
Read the letter https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X

<U+0001F1E7><U+0001F1F7> NDC lacks consultation, transparency & participation from civil society, academia & scientists. The NDC says "institutional interactions between government & civil society take place through the Brazilian Forum on Climate change". There was no interaction in this process.

The <U+0001F1E7><U+0001F1F7> NDC submitted on 9 December 2020 fails to increase ambition and is in fact a regression from the previous NDC. As the sixth largest global GHG emitter, and a key economy in Latin America, Brazil has a critical role to stop the climate crisis.

Specific clauses in the #ParisAgreement explain the progression principle on climate ambition, and any regression or backsliding in the ambition of updated or successive NDCs is a violation of the #ParisAgreement and will delay urgent climate action.

As countries continue to share their updated nationally determined contributions (NDC), it is important to call out those submitting weak & regressive NDCs that slide back on ambition and threaten the integrity of the #ParisAgreement & delay action on the climate crisis.

Led by Brazilian civil society groups, @CANIntl has issued a  letter to @UNFCCC about worrying red flags in Brazil's nationally determined contribution (NDC) submitted in December 9, 2020 that threatens to undermine the integrity of the #ParisAgreement --> https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X https://t.co/JNf8lswXGD

See what the corporate gigaton challenge is all about. Allowing companies to offset their #CO2 internally while sequestering a gigaton of carbon. https://t.co/uN4yvYmaxQ
@Peters_Glen That is why we need to look at other solutions to #DirectAirCapture. #CO2 sequestration into deep oceans using #WaveEnergy is just one affordable & feasible alternatives.

After two tests showing active down pumping of surface water using #WaveEnergy (ie Sinking #Carbon rich water; #sequestering #CO2), moving towards a non collapsible tube which allowing #saltfountain to establish, thereby increasing rate of #downwelling. A economic carbon sink

Second #ocean test 1/3 scaled system completed July 11th off coast of #MorroBay #California. Inlet pump resized to optimize #downwelling of #Carbon rich water as we move closer to realizing cost effective way to #SequesterCarbon #CO2. https://t.co/d2PK1XMXax
@TEDTalks We need to find cost effective ways to #SinkCarbon. Using #WaveEnergy, we aim to #sequester 1 #gigaton within 5 years. #Corporates can internalize #CO2 & fund the #gigatonchallenge
Set for our next #OceanBased test July 12th off the west coast as we refine our #WaveEnergy pump designed to #SinkCarbon in the deep #oceans. #SequesterCarbon, negative #CO2

Huge success in deploying 1/3 scale size #OSCAR (Ocean Surface Carbon Relocation) system off coast of #SanDiego demonstrating we can use #WaveEnergy to send #CO2 to ocean depth, realizing #sequestration. https://t.co/AjLHpGJbTn
@Co2Coalition Where is your 'readily' available data?
Off to #SanDiego tomorrow for our first #CarbonSequestration field test. Using #WaveEnergy, we aim to sink #Carbon / #CO2
Great to attend this years #OceanMixingConference! Understanding our #ocean cycles better allows us to better plan for #CarbonSequestration.  https://t.co/amv44DPJ5B

@OlivineCO2 Ultimately we are responsible for all the #CO2 we emit. Even with #Sequestration like our system that #Sinks carbon in the oceans using #WaveEnergy, it will forever remain in our ecological / geological cycles. #Sequestration is a mitigation & time extension tool.
